itemLabel: Kaplica Czaszek: The Chapel of Skulls
description: The walls and ceiling of this Polish church are decorated with thousands of skulls, with another 21,000 skeletons just below.
Beneath Kraków Old Town's main square lies a hologram-filled medieval market vampire graveyard wonderland.
Countless stories attempt to explain Poland's mysterious J-shaped trees.
An underground city of salt.

itemLabel: The Bones of the Wawel Dragon
description: Real bones which are said to have belonged to a Polish dragon.
This Polish cave has housed a dragon, a brothel, and an enduring legend.
The site of the first battle of World War II.
A program of Communist glamour in post-Stalin Poland is preserved in this colorful museum.
The former Nazi concentration camp stands as a museum to remember this dark chapter in European history.
A fairytale Gothic castle steeped in Nazi treasure conspiracy theories.
This Nazi ruin was the site where Hitler was almost blown up by a suitcase bomb.
A hidden art gallery in an abandoned Warsaw fort.
After the famous composer died in Paris, his sister snuck his heart out of the country to honor his wish that it be buried in their native country.
This uber-quaint Polish village is known for its habit of painting elaborate floral motifs on just about everything.
This 700-year-old structure is one of the most unique architectural and historic monuments in Gdańsk.
Warsaw's fantastically preserved gasworks...almost.
Poland's oldest surviving university building holds a wealth of historic science instruments including some used by Copernicus.
St. Mary's features one of the most spectacularly decorated cathedral interiors in all of Europe.
The unsettling remnants of a torn down movie set lies nearby the ruined location of the actual Płaszów Labor Camp.
This man-made mound monument was built out of soil from all across the Polish empire.

itemLabel: Czar PRL: Life Under Communism Museum
description: This hidden collection of everyday objects illustrates life within communist Poland.
The world’s narrowest house makes for an awkward, four-foot-wide living space.
A tribute to the Polish insurgents who fought in the failed attempt to end their city's Nazi occupation.
Communism's topsy-turvy effect on Poland has been brought to life in this wacky tourist trap.
A memorial to the beloved brown bear that served in the Polish army during World War II.
A menacing statue of this mythical creature can be seen at the legendary site of the monster's lair.
A national collection of Communist-era musical posters.
The final resting place of more than 200,000 people, this is one of the largest cemeteries in Europe.
This sprawling concrete suburb of Kraków was designed by the Soviet Union as the model proletarian city.
A huge wooden clock that is so beautiful its creator was forcibly blinded.
Naturally formed rock city in Poland.
Order “Proletariat’s Cutlet” at this communist-themed restaurant allegedly once visited by Lenin.
A collection of old neon signs from all over Poland line a secluded courtyard.
A 20th-century picture show in 3-D.
A peculiar family mausoleum built by a German nobleman captivated by the occult.
These massive moving sand dunes have swallowed an entire village and are still on the run.
An abandoned Nazi explosives plant founded by the inventor of dynamite is now an underground museum.
Museum dedicated to "the man who moved the Earth."
This biographical museum honors the groundbreaking scientist at her birthplace in Warsaw.
This imposing 20th-century castle was abandoned before it was ever completed.
At first glance, this area seems like just another city park, but the lush landscape hides a dark past.
Crosses of all shapes, sizes and colors litter the mountain, the site of a huge yearly Orthodox pilgrimage.
A haunting deserted hotel is a favorite with artists and photographers.
Polish luminaries and masterful folk art find sanctuary in this unique cemetery.
This centuries-old wooden wonder was built in less than a year and is one of Europe's largest timber-framed churches.
A statue honors the children who fought Nazis in Poland.
The traditional Polish croissant, folded 81 times into the shape of a horseshoe, is a legally protected cultural treat.
The Polish capital has had a deep connection to its guardian mermaid for almost a millennium now.
There are thousands of tributes and memorials to the King, but none quite like this one in a Kraków city park.
Once a giant gingerbread factory, this space now hosts exhibits and workshops on the historic treat.

itemLabel: Church of St. Francis of Assisi
description: Inside this Krakow church, an explosion of psychedelic color.
The silly symbol for an underground protest group is now scattered around the city.
A mysterious structure left behind on the Polish mountainside, sometimes called "Hitler's Stonehenge".
One of the world's largest collections of medieval religious art.
A striking public sculpture representing the period of martial law in Communist Poland.

itemLabel: The Museum of Dollhouses, Games and Toys
description: A delightful museum entirely dedicated to the tiny homes of dolls.
This 13th century Gothic brick castle is the largest in the world by surface area.
This fairytale inspired, warped building houses restaurants, shops, and a radio station.
A 90-ton, gravity-defiant steam locomotive shoots for the skies in this bizarrely beautiful public artwork.
Poland's oldest salt mine has nearly everything one needs to live underground forever.
This fairytale medieval church in Poland originally spent centuries in Norway.
What was once an underground Nazi city is now Europe's largest bat reserve.
An abandoned Jewish sanatorium is tucked within the woods of Poland.
This grubby wall is said to be one of the Earth's esoteric energy centers.
Deep in a Polish forest, this collection of Iron Age megaliths still holds onto many of its ancient secrets.
Boats must transform into railroad cars to navigate this Polish canal.
A World War II torpedo launch station abandoned off the Polish coast.
A floundering Polish shipyard was once the soul of the Solidarity movement that capsized communism.
A tree planted by Marie Curie is treasured by the Radium institute that she set up.

itemLabel: Old Prussian Hags of Northern Pomerania
description: These rare statues are one of the few remaining material witnesses to Old Prussian culture.
Special benches that play Chopin's music are scattered throughout his native city.
In northeastern Poland, the ruins of a massive granary overlook the Narew River.
The giant statue and its model solar system honor the native Pole who declared that the Earth revolves around the Sun.

itemLabel: The Three Boar Heads of Gdańsk
description: A mysterious emblem tucked in an small alleyway is actually the coat of arms of a heroic medieval family.
This picturesque castle in Poland has a rich history, including a legend that ties it to lost Incan treasures.
This oddly beautiful water cistern is a techno-temple to the wet stuff and a multimedia masterpiece.
Memorial to the lost dead of Gdansk, whose resting places were destroyed during World War II.
A merchant court dedicated to the fictitious King Arthur is heavily adorned with bizarre Renaissance art.

itemLabel: The Living Obwarzanek Museum (Żywe Muzeum Obwarzanka)
description: Learn the fine art of making a centuries-old treat at this hands-on food museum.
Legend says this is actually a heartbroken prince waiting for his true love's kiss.
The hollow trunk of this 650-year-old tree was used as a hideout by two Jewish brothers during World War II.
One of the largest amphitheaters in Europe is a former Nazi gathering place that still stands today.
This bell stars in a tragic love tale and is said to make wishes come true.
This antique thermometer honors the creator of the first universal temperature scale.
In the midst of a living monument to Soviet social engineering, Polish Catholics built this church by hand.
Dubbed "Wistom" by locals, this abandoned factory is an urban explorer's dream.
These mechanical goats first battled it out in the year 1551, all because of an overcooked deer.
This tower in a small Polish village uses the power of a sacred bell to ward off mischievous weather spirits.
This enormous 32-foot painting depicts Poland's greatest medieval battle in glorious detail.
This open-air museum was originally a World War II testing ground for German missiles and rockets.
One of only two places in the world where two rivers cross each other without the waters mixing.
This mysterious and once-grand memorial still embodies a remarkable architectural vision.
This extensive collection covers thousands of years of Polish military history.
These 18th-century paintings of Warsaw were used to reconstruct the city after World War II.

itemLabel: Stalag Luft III Prisoner Camp Museum
description: The site of one of the largest prison escapes of World War II.
This Communist-era residential block is one of the longest residential building in Europe.
The largest toy museum in Poland showcases Europe's history of childhood.
A monument to Poland's famous alleged UFO abduction case.
A collection of modern and vintage pinball machines housed in the cellar of a 15th-century building.
In the summer, the area around this sculpture transforms into a vibrant concert venue.

itemLabel: Monument In Honor of the Slaughtered Animals
description: In the center of Wrocław's old meat market stands a somber tribute to the city's livestock.

itemLabel: Monument to the Defenders of the Polish Post Office
description: Modern art commemorates one of the first military actions of World War II.
A small granite monument marks where the borders of three countries meet.
While the U.S. and Soviet Union were engaged in a space race, Poland built a UFO on the ground.
An abandoned football stadium with a tragic past.

itemLabel: Museum of Soap and History of Dirt
description: Come to this Polish museum to take a good, clean look at filth.
Hundreds of notes give thanks to the patron saint of lost causes.
On this Polish road, an optical illusion makes cars seem to roll uphill.
The coffin-shaped church was once home to monks who slept in coffins.
Brought to you by the makers of fiberglass dinosaurs.
The two abandoned overpasses are among the largest bridges in Poland.
Relive a Polish uprising via an enormous, century-old cyclorama.
Atop this library is one of the most beautiful green spaces in Warsaw.
A statue commemorating a Polish dog who took his role as man's best friend very seriously.
The giant metal fruit was once the symbol of a large farm.

itemLabel: Internet Antennas of Christ the King
description: This towering statue of Jesus provided internet to the surrounding area.
An open-air museum of 18th-century homes and churches transported from various villages in Southern Poland.
Built to transport German U-boats through the never-completed Masurian Canal, the locks near this Polish village are now home to a rope course.
An artificial hill and apparent calendric structure built in the Early Middle Ages immortalizes a legendary Polish princess.
Old cabin-like homes in a rural community untouched by time are known for their vibrant and colorful window shutters.
This hilltop ruin is of the hundreds of stone columns built in tribute to the first German chancellor.

itemLabel: The Dental Museum and Mummy of Racibórz
description: The biggest exposition of dental equipement in Europe. And a Mummy.
This colorful and quirky set of pegasus sculptures celebrate the works of poet Zbigniew Herbert.
A somber memorial honors the hundreds of thousands of lives lost at this labor and extermination camp.
People in Poland have rallied to save this unnatural desert from being reclaimed by the forest.
A stone in Wolin, Poland, marks the possible location of a legendary Viking fortress.
The final resting place of the last "gypsy king" of Poland.
A cluster of headless, armless sculptures looms within a popular Polish park.
The first, and perhaps only, monument dedicated to Wikipedia.
The majority of the highest mountain in Poland is actually located in a different country.
The oldest wind turbine in Europe, constructed by a group of friends in 1932.
Extremely famous in his native country, this Cracovian painter is all but unknown beyond Polish borders.
The last king of Poland was interred in this church nearly 200 years after his death.
This unique railroad museum secretly contains the history of Poland rebuilding itself from the inside-out.
This museum in the tower of the oldest church in Gdańsk, is home to centuries-old time-keeping devices and the world's first pulsar clock.

itemLabel: Memorial to the Victims of Air Pollution
description: Down this Cracovian street resides a plaque with a stark message about the city's air pollution.
An artificial date palm stands as a memorial to Warsaw's Jewish community.
A bronze replica of an elm tree that honors the victims that perished in Pawaik Prison.
The relics are stored in a silver reliquary, where they can be seen through glass.
The shattered remains of the world's once tallest structure.
The manor house where the Polish composer spent childhood summer holidays is now a museum and concert hall.
Once home to some 250,000 volumes and priceless art artifacts, this Polish estate was a target of bombing during World War II.
Gliwice Radio Tower, likely the tallest wooden structure in the world.
A miniatures park with a model of Wolf's Lair as it looked during World War II.
An impressive monument to Poland's independence.
A heavily politicized roundabout discussing the state of a heavily politicized country.

itemLabel: The Secret Polish Eagle on Fara Church
description: This symbol of Polish heritage survived the occupation during World War II, hidden in plain sight.
An extensive network of secret tunnels was created for the Nazi project "Riese."
Disturbing works of outsider art, carved from whole logs.
At night, this memorial illuminates a ghostly outline of a footbridge that connected two sections of the Warsaw Ghetto.
Legend says a giant, venomous spider once dwelled within this Polish church.
These plaques found across Warsaw commemorate the sites where executions or battles took place during the German occupation.
A marker honors the brief peace found by a tormented artist in the fictional land of Kcymaerxthaere.
One of the world's largest amber altarpieces is housed within this reconstructed medieval church.
An underground city beneath Krakow's postwar socialist utopia.
Where visitors can play more than 150 retro arcade games.

itemLabel: Grzyb skalny w Zegartowice (Zegartowice Mushroom Rock)
description: This mushroom-shaped rock has frustrated and fascinated locals for centuries.
This lakeside bunker complex in Mamerki, Poland, housed the Supreme Military Command of Nazi Germany during World War II.
This formerly-prosperous Silesian mining town was completely demolished in the late 1960s and early 1970s as an attempt to cover up a secret Soviet uranium mine.
This ex-prison dates back to the Middle Ages.
Catch a scenic view of Warsaw's Old Town from the top of a centuries-old dumping ground.
A tribute to the first human in space.
Remnants from a time before electricity.

itemLabel: The Disappeared City Center of Kostrzyn
description: The center of this Polish border town was so thoroughly wiped out in World War II that only the foundations remain.
Krakow's own version of the Hollywood Walk of Fame.
A mysterious concrete hand reaches out from between the stones of Uniwersytecki bridge.
A massive mammoth bone has been on display inside this church since the 18th century.

itemLabel: National Museum of Technology in Warsaw
description: This museum houses and extensive collection of technology contributed by the Polish people.
A Soviet era flat that refused to conform to the dull gray standards.
This abandoned but well-preserved Prussian fortress sits abandoned in a Polish forest near the German border.
This wooden mosque is one of the few remnants of medieval Poland's Muslim Tatar community in this deeply Catholic country.
This 16th-century pole was once used in brutal public executions.
This dazzling wooden church was constructed as part of an elaborate peace project after the Thirty Years' War.

itemLabel: Archaeological Remains at Hala Targowa (Market Hall)
description: Several 12th-century ruins can be found inside this historical market.
The last original stone marking the interwar border between Germany and Poland sits in this unassuming village park.
During the renovation of this bas-relief, the constructors added one unusual element.
A small square populated with giant birchwood sculptures.
A Bauhaus co-founder designed this quirky, abandoned granary.

itemLabel: Beached Wreck of the Warship Grom II
description: The rusting hulk of a Soviet warship sits on a Polish beach.
A large boar commemorates the city's founding and the origin of its name.
These beautiful castle ruins are nestled in the Polish countryside.
This Baltic beauty is rumored to grant a wish and a half.
Gdańsk's lion mascot features in a trail of bronze sculptures scattered all across the city.
An early creation by Erich Mendelsohn.
The tallest stone dam in Poland was opened by Kaiser Wilhelm II himself.
For 200 years, people have flocked to this Polish town to experience the healing powers of salt.
This public park collects signposts and other memorabilia related to local history, Polish-German relations and human progress
Ruins of a late 1950s Polish ski jump ramp in the middle of the city.
This now-defunct synthetic fuel plant was once a major cog in the Nazi war machine.
